originInfo.publisher: Administrative Office of the United States Courts

name.namePart: United States District Court Northern District of New York

titleInfo.title: Campbell v. Colvin
titleInfo.subTitle: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS re 1 Complaint filed by Joanne C. Campbell. RECOMMENDED that the Commissioner's decision should be REVERSED, and the case REMANDED pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 405(g), sentence four, with instructions to admit into the evidentiary record the medical SUNY Health Science Center records that were "looked at" by the Appeals Council, but misplaced and not made part of the administrative transcript. The Commissioner should further be instructed to (a) reassess credibility of treating physician opinion and subjective testimony in light of the new evidence and existing evidence from the consulting rheumatologist, and (b) redetermine Campbell's residual functional capacity, all without regard to whether objective corroborating evidence of fibromyalgia and its limiting functional effects exists. Objections to R&R due by 12/4/2014 Signed by Magistrate Judge Earl S. Hines on 11/14/2014. (see)

extension.courtName: United States District Court Northern District of New York
extension.docketText: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS re 1 Complaint filed by Joanne C. Campbell. RECOMMENDED that the Commissioner's decision should be REVERSED, and the case REMANDED pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 405(g), sentence four, with instructions to admit into the evidentiary record the medical SUNY Health Science Center records that were "looked at" by the Appeals Council, but misplaced and not made part of the administrative transcript. The Commissioner should further be instructed to (a) reassess credibility of treating physician opinion and subjective testimony in light of the new evidence and existing evidence from the consulting rheumatologist, and (b) redetermine Campbell's residual functional capacity, all without regard to whether objective corroborating evidence of fibromyalgia and its limiting functional effects exists. Objections to R&R due by 12/4/2014 Signed by Magistrate Judge Earl S. Hines on 11/14/2014. (see)

titleInfo.title: Campbell v. Colvin
titleInfo.subTitle: ORDER - That the 32 Report-Recommendation of Magistrate Judge Earl S. Hines filed November 17, 2014 is ACCEPTED in its entirety for the reasons stated therein; and it is further ORDERED that the Commissioners decision is REVERSED, and the case is REMANDED pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 405(g), sentence four, with instructions to admit into the evidentiary record the medical SUNY Health Sciences Center records that were looked at by the Appeals Council, but misplaced and not made part of the administrative transcript (i.e., Doc. No. 17, Ex. B). The Commissioner is further instructed to (a) reassess credibility of treating physician opinion and subjective testimony in light of the new evidence and existing evidence from the consulting rheumatologist, and (b) redetermine Campbells residual functional capacity, all without regard to whether objective corroborating evidence of fibromyalgia and its limiting functional effects exist. Signed by Chief Judge Gary L. Sharpe on 1/6/2015. (jel, )

extension.courtName: United States District Court Northern District of New York
extension.docketText: ORDER - That the 32 Report-Recommendation of Magistrate Judge Earl S. Hines filed November 17, 2014 is ACCEPTED in its entirety for the reasons stated therein; and it is further ORDERED that the Commissioners decision is REVERSED, and the case is REMANDED pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 405(g), sentence four, with instructions to admit into the evidentiary record the medical SUNY Health Sciences Center records that were looked at by the Appeals Council, but misplaced and not made part of the administrative transcript (i.e., Doc. No. 17, Ex. B). The Commissioner is further instructed to (a) reassess credibility of treating physician opinion and subjective testimony in light of the new evidence and existing evidence from the consulting rheumatologist, and (b) redetermine Campbells residual functional capacity, all without regard to whether objective corroborating evidence of fibromyalgia and its limiting functional effects exist. Signed by Chief Judge Gary L. Sharpe on 1/6/2015. (jel, )
